Seventh Chords
• Five types of seventh chords are commonly used.
• Dominant seventh chords are abbreviated with a simple 7.
• Let's examine a C dominant seventh chord.
• C—E—G is the major triad.
• C—B♭ is the minor seventh.
• When combined, they form a C dominant seventh chord: C—E—G—B♭.
• Next, let's examine an F♯ dominant seventh chord.
• F♯—A♯—C♯ is the major triad.
• F♯—E is the minor seventh.
• When combined, they form an F♯ dominant seventh chord: F♯—A♯—C♯—E.
• Next, let's examine an A♭ dominant seventh chord.
• A♭—C—E♭ is the major triad.
• A♭—G♭ is the minor seventh.
• When combined, they form an A♭ dominant seventh chord: A♭—C—E♭—G♭.
• Major seventh chords are abbreviated with a capital "M" and a 7.
• Let's examine a C major seventh chord.
• C—E—G is the major triad.
• C—B is the major seventh.
• When combined, they form a C major seventh chord: C—E—G—B.
• Next, let's examine an F♯ major seventh chord.
• F♯—A♯—C♯ is the major triad.
• F♯—E♯ is the major seventh.
• When combined, they form an F♯ major seventh chord: F♯—A♯—C♯—E♯.
• Next, let's examine an A♭ major seventh chord.
• A♭—C—E♭ is the major triad.
• A♭—G is the major seventh.
• When combined, they form an A♭ major seventh chord: A♭—C—E♭—G.
• Minor seventh chords are abbreviated with a lower-case "m" and a 7.
• Let's examine a C minor seventh chord.
• C—E♭—G is the minor triad.
• C—B♭ is the minor seventh.
• When combined, they form a C minor seventh chord: C—E♭—G—B♭.
• Next, let's examine an F♯ minor seventh chord.
• F♯—A—C♯ is the minor triad.
• F♯—E is the minor seventh.
• When combined, they form an F♯ minor seventh chord: F♯—A—C♯—E.
• Next, let's examine an A♭ minor seventh chord.
• A♭—C♭—E♭ is the minor triad.
• A♭—G♭ is the minor seventh.
• When combined, they form an A♭ minor seventh chord: A♭—C♭—E♭—G♭.
• Half-diminished seventh chords are abbreviated with a slashed circle and a 7.
• Let's examine a C half-diminished seventh chord.
• C—E♭—G♭ is the diminished triad.
• C—B♭ is the minor seventh.
• When combined, they form a C half-diminished seventh chord: C—E♭—G♭—B♭.
• Next, let's examine an F♯ half-diminished seventh chord.
• F♯—A—C is the diminished triad.
• F♯—E is the minor seventh.
• When combined, they form an F♯ half-diminished seventh chord: F♯—A—C—E.
• Next, let's examine an A♭ half-diminished seventh chord.
• A♭—C♭—E♭♭ is the diminished triad.
• A♭—G♭ is the minor seventh.
• When combined, they form an A♭ half-diminished seventh chord: A♭—C♭—E♭♭—G♭.
• Diminished seventh chords are abbreviated with an open circle and a 7.
• Let's examine a C diminished seventh chord.
• C—E♭—G♭ is the diminished triad.
• C—B♭♭ is the diminished seventh.
• When combined, they form a C diminished seventh chord: C—E♭—G♭—B♭♭.
• Next, let's examine an F♯ diminished seventh chord.
• F♯—A—C is the diminished triad.
• F♯—E♭ is the diminished seventh.
• When combined, they form an F♯ diminished seventh chord: F♯—A—C—E♭.
• Next, let's examine an A♭ diminished seventh chord.
• A♭—C♭—E♭♭ is the diminished triad.
• A♭—G♭♭ is the diminished seventh.
• When combined, they form an A♭ diminished seventh chord: A♭—C♭—E♭♭—G♭♭.
